prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. So the user is asking if the person who wrote the situation is in the wrong. The scenario is about a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife who also works from home and handles most of the chores and kids. The wife suggested the basement, but he chose the bedroom for the view. Now she can't do basic things like shower or take a nap when he's on calls. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he stays in the bedroom, and they're fighting about it.

First, I need to evaluate both sides. The husband's choice to work in the bedroom might be inconvenient, but the wife is handling a lot of responsibilities. The key points here are about mutual consideration and the setup of shared spaces. The wife is trying to balance her work and household duties, which are also important. The husband's job is mostly conference calls, which require silence, but the wife can't function properly if the bedroom is off-limits.

The question is whether the wife is in the wrong for not keeping him undisturbed. The wife isn't at fault here because the husband's decision to place his office in the bedroom created the conflict. The wife is trying to manage her own work and household responsibilities, and asking him to move to the basement is a reasonable request. By choosing the bedroom, he's making it harder for her to do her tasks. So the husband's choice is the root of the problem, not the wife's inability to keep the bedroom quiet. The wife's stance that she can't promise silence is valid because she can't control the kids or other household activities in the bedroom. Therefore, the author (wife) is not in the wrong. The answer should be B.
